docs.lead_paragraph: PHYSICIANS and pharmacists fail to give nearly 80 percent of their patients any precautionary instructions on prescription drugs and hardly any consumer asks questions, according to a national survey done for the Food and Drug Administration. ''The consequences of this lack of communication are serious,'' Paul G. Rogers, a former Democratic Representative from Florida and chairman of the National Council on Patient Information and Education, said recently. ''Ten percent of all prescriptions written are not filled, 50 percent of all prescriptions filled are not taken correctly. People do not get well, suffer avoidable side effects or are hospitalized for drug misuse.''
